name: Sam Westrick
content: Sam Westrick Sam Westrick s (dogoodt) we!stricluckk (a!t) nyrobotsu (do!t) ed!u 60 Fifth Ave, Room 308 CIMS Computer Science Department New York University New York, NY I am an assistant professor of computer science in the Courant Institute at New York University, where I lead the ParCour lab and am a member of ACSys. My research focuses on provably efficient and safe implementations of high-level programming languages, especially for parallel programming. The goal is to make it simpler and safer to develop parallel software by providing strong guarantees on not only safety, but also performance. Two examples from my work include (1) provably efficient parallel garbage collection based on disentanglement, and (2) provably efficient automatic granularity control. Previously, I was a post-doc at Carnegie Mellon University, working with Umut Acar. I completed my PhD at Carnegie Mellon in 2022. (Nov 17, 2023) We have two papers accepted at POPL'24! See paper list below. (June 21, 2023) I am the 2023 recipient of the SIGPLAN Reynolds Doctoral Dissertation Award. MaPLe (MPL) I lead development of MaPLe (MPL for short), an efficient and scalable parallel functional programming language. MaPLe offers excellent multicore performance through a combination of provably efficient parallel garbage collection and automatic granularity control. Across a wide range of parallel algorithms and benchmarks (see our benchmark suite), we have shown that MaPLe can compete with languages such as C/C++ in terms of time and space efficiency. As a functional language, MaPLe makes it easy to avoid data races and unintended race conditions. MaPLe is currently being used at New York University and Carnegie Mellon University to help teach parallel programming to hundreds of students every year. MaPLe is open-source!
